description: Enhanced Japanese → Vietnamese Particle Mapping System (Archetype-Aware & Corpus-Validated)

selection_priority: 1. Check character archetype for archetype_specific mappings
3. Check gender association (if character has gender defined)
6. Fall back to default mapping if no specific match

よ (yo).function: Emphasis, assertion, informing (speaker knows something listener doesn't)

archetype_variants.GYARU: Đây là sự thật luôn nha!

usage_notes: よ is one of most frequent particles - appears ~18k times in corpus
Default Vietnamese: 'đấy' (northern), 'đó' (neutral/southern)
'mà' adds explanation/insistence nuance
KUUDERE characters often omit entirely for minimalism
GYARU/GENKI types intensify with 'luôn' or multiple particles
OJOU types soften to 'ạ' to maintain refinement
common_mistakes: Over-translating to 'nhé' (that's ね, not よ)
Using 'đấy' for questions (that's か, not よ)
Missing the assertive tone in casual contexts

usage_notes: ね seeks agreement, よ asserts information - critical distinction
'nhỉ' for wondering/rhetorical, 'nhé' for gentle commands
Very common in female speech, less in rough male speech
KUUDERE/DELINQUENT often drop or replace with harder particles
Can combine with よ as よね → 'đúng không' / 'phải không'
common_mistakes: Confusing ね (agreement) with よ (assertion)
Using 'nhé' for statements (should be 'nhỉ')
Missing the warmth/softness in intimate contexts

な (na).function: Masculine informal agreement-seeking, contemplation, prohibition (depending on position)

DEREDERE: nhỉ (rare - more feminine char uses ね)

usage_notes: な has two functions: (1) sentence-final contemplation (2) prohibition suffix
Male-dominant particle - avoid for feminine characters
Prohibition な is absolute command: 動詞るな = đừng + verb
DELINQUENT/SHOUNEN_MC use frequently, OJOU/GYARU never use
Vietnamese 'nhể' captures rough masculine tone better than 'nhỉ'
common_mistakes: Using for female characters (use ね instead)
Confusing prohibition な with sentence-final な
Over-softening to 'nhé' (loses masculine edge)

わ (wa).function: Feminine assertion, soft emphasis (archaic/dialectal in modern Japanese)

TSUNDERE: (rarely use わ - use よ instead)

archetype_variants.YAMATO_NADESHIKO: Điều đó không đúng lắm ạ.

usage_notes: わ is signature OJOU particle when combined with です/ます (ですわ/ますわ)
Modern speakers rarely use わ alone (sounds archaic)
In Vietnamese, OJOU characters maintain elegance with 'ạ'
GYARU/modern casual female characters use よ instead
When translating ですわ/ますわ, add both 'ạ' and formal register
common_mistakes: Using わ mapping for modern casual female speech
Missing OJOU archetype detection when わ appears
Over-translating to 'mà' (loses feminine elegance)

examples.literal: Tao sẽ bảo vệ mày đó!

archetype_variants.SHOUNEN_MC: Tôi sẽ bảo vệ cậu đó!
archetype_variants.DELINQUENT: Tao sẽ bảo vệ mày này!
archetype_variants.SENPAI: Anh sẽ bảo vệ em đấy.

usage_notes: ぞ is exclusively masculine - never for female characters
Stronger than よ - shows determination, challenge, or warning
DELINQUENT/SHOUNEN_MC signature particle
Vietnamese 'này' captures aggressive edge best
Can combine with 行くぞ (Let's go!) pattern → 'Đi đây!' or 'Đi thôi!'
common_mistakes: Using for female characters
Under-translating to neutral particles
Missing the urgent/commanding tone

ぜ (ze).function: Casual masculine emphasis, showing off, rough friendliness
usage_notes: ぜ is rougher/more casual than ぞ
Common in delinquent/yankee speech
Shows confidence, bragging, or rough affection
Exclusively male - never for female characters
Vietnamese 'đó' works well for casual tone
common_mistakes: Confusing with ぞ (ぜ is more casual/friendly)
Using for female characters
Over-formalizing the translation

usage_notes: の as sentence-final is feminine (different from possessive の)
Adds explanatory/vulnerable nuance
Common in female characters' questions and statements
TSUNDERE use の during dere moments (vulnerability)
Vietnamese 'à/hả/vậy' captures the soft inquisitive tone
Avoid for masculine/stoic characters
common_mistakes: Confusing sentence-final の with possessive の
Using for male characters (masculine speech avoids this の)
Missing the explanatory nuance in statements

usage_notes: Most common question particle - ~22k instances
Formality depends on verb form: ですか (polite) vs dictionary か (casual)
Can be dropped in casual speech (rising intonation alone)
Vietnamese default: 'không' for yes/no, 'à/hả/sao' for WH-questions
OJOU always adds 'ạ', GYARU uses 'hả/hử', KUUDERE minimal
common_mistakes: Always translating to 'không' (should vary by question type)
Missing formality markers for formal archetypes
Over-translating casual か (sometimes omit in Vietnamese)

かな (kana).function: Wondering, thinking aloud, seeking soft confirmation

examples.literal: Cô ấy có đến không nhỉ

archetype_variants.TSUNDERE: Cô ấy... có đến không nhỉ...
archetype_variants.DEREDERE: Cô ấy có đến không nhỉ~
archetype_variants.BROODING: Cô ấy có đến không ta...

usage_notes: かな expresses internal deliberation or soft wondering
More contemplative than か alone
'nhỉ' captures wondering tone well
'ta' adds literary/contemplative flavor (good for BROODING/SCHOLAR)
TSUNDERE uses かな during vulnerable moments
KUUDERE often omit (too expressive for stoic characters)
common_mistakes: Confusing with strong questions (use か not かな)
Missing the contemplative/vulnerable tone
Over-using 'không biết' (too explicit)

だよね (da yo ne).function: Seeking confirmation with emphasis (right? isn't it?)

archetype_variants.GYARU: Người đó lạ đúng không nè?

archetype_variants.OJOU: Cái này đúng phải không ạ?

usage_notes: Combination of よ (assertion) + ね (agreement-seeking)
'đúng không' and 'phải không' are standard Vietnamese equivalents
Very common in casual dialogue for validation
GYARU might add 'nè' for flavor
KUUDERE avoid seeking validation (use flat statement)
common_mistakes: Translating as pure question (missing the validation aspect)
Over-formalizing with 'có phải không' (too formal)
Missing archetype-specific softeners/intensifiers

でしょ (desho).function: Casual seeking agreement (だろう casual form), 'right?'
usage_notes: でしょ is casual form of でしょう (presumption + agreement-seeking)
Often used for 'I told you so' situations
Vietnamese 'mà' captures the 'see, I was right' tone
'đúng không' for neutral agreement-seeking
TSUNDERE classic particle for vindication moments
common_mistakes: Missing the 'I told you so' nuance when context warrants
Over-formalizing to 'có phải không'
Not adjusting for archetype intensity

usage_notes: だろ is masculine casual form of でしょう
Shows assumption/presumption with confidence
Never for female characters (use でしょ)
'chứ' captures masculine assertive tone
'đúng không' for neutral masculine confirmation
common_mistakes: Using for female characters
Not capturing masculine confidence
Over-softening the translation

usage_notes: ちょっと extremely common (16k+ instances) for softening
Vietnamese 'tí/tẹo' more casual, 'một chút' more neutral
Can often be omitted and softness conveyed through particles
DELINQUENT/KUUDERE rarely soften (skip ちょっと)
IMOUTO/DEREDERE use frequently with cute particles
なんか adds vagueness/hedging to statements
'kiểu' popular among young Vietnamese speakers (GYARU affinity)
'hơi' more neutral hedging
Can often omit in Vietnamese (over-use sounds unnatural)
KUUDERE/DELINQUENT skip hedging (too direct)
まあ shows resignation/acceptance (not enthusiastic)
'thôi' captures resignation tone well
'cũng được' for reluctant acceptance
TSUNDERE use during dere moments (giving in)
Can sometimes omit and convey through tone
ですわ/ますわ is OJOU archetype marker
Always add 'ạ' in Vietnamese to maintain elegance
May use classical pronouns: thiếp, nàng, ngài
CRITICAL: Detection of わ with polite form should trigger OJOU archetype
Never used by modern casual female characters
じゃん is casual youth slang (Tokyo/Kanagawa region)
GYARU archetype marker
Vietnamese 'mà' works well for casual assertion
Never for formal characters (OJOU, YAMATO_NADESHIKO)
Detection of じゃん suggests young casual character
っしょ is ultra-casual contracted でしょ
Strong GYARU marker
Shows extreme casualness/youth slang
Never for formal/elegant characters

vietnamese_mappings.dialect_note: If character uses Kansai dialect, may add southern Vietnamese particles

usage_notes: やん is Kansai dialect marker
Similar function to じゃん but regional
Vietnamese: consider southern particles (nè, nghe) if character is dialectal
Standard mapping: 'mà/chứ'
で is Kansai sentence-final particle
Indicates regional speech pattern
Vietnamese: 'đó' captures casual assertion
さ is casual masculine filler/emphasis
Can often omit in Vietnamese
When kept, 'đấy/mà' work well

examples.jp: だって好きなんだもん

usage_notes: もん is childish/cute particle
Strong IMOUTO/CHILD archetype marker
TSUNDERE use when being defensive
Vietnamese 'mà/chứ' capture excuse/defense tone
Never for mature/elegant characters

～し (shi).function: Listing reasons, emphasis on multiple points

vietnamese_mappings.translation_strategy: Often translate by listing reasons naturally

examples.jp: 時間もないし、お金もないし
examples.vn: Không có thời gian, lại không có tiền nữa

usage_notes: し lists reasons/observations casually
Vietnamese: use natural listing (vừa...lại vừa, mà...lại)
Can use 'mà' to connect, but often better to restructure
Avoid literal 'và' (too formal for casual し)

examples.jp: 頑張ったのに失敗した
examples.vn: Đã cố gắng mà vẫn thất bại

examples.jp: 行きたいけど、時間がない
examples.vn: Muốn đi nhưng không có thời gian

integration_instructions: 2. During JP→VN translation, detect Japanese particles in source
4. Look up particle in this database
5. Select Vietnamese mapping based on archetype_specific if available
8. Apply gender filter if character gender defined
9. Fall back to default mapping if no specific match
10. Inject selected Vietnamese particle into translation

priority_handling.critical: Always process these particles (よ, ね, か - 50k+ combined frequency)
priority_handling.high: Process when detected (な, わ, ぞ, かな, etc.)

common_translation_pitfalls: Don't translate all よ as 'nhé' (that's ね)
Don't use masculine particles for female characters
Don't miss archetype-specific variants (OJOU speaking like GYARU breaks character)
Don't over-translate hedges (なんか, ちょっと often omitted in Vietnamese)
Don't under-translate emphasis (ぞ, ぜ need aggressive Vietnamese particles)
Don't confuse sentence-final の (feminine) with possessive の
validation_checklist: ✓ Particle frequency feels natural (not every sentence)
